posts.cooked:
Hello! My team has been trying to use PathPlanner for following paths during auto, but we are having a problem with power cycling the robot. When code is deployed to the robot, and autos are run immediately after, the robot follows the path directly. However, upon power cycling the robot, the path that our robot takes is completely messed up.

What we found by logging and printing values is that when we deployed code and ran the autos right afterwards, our odometry pose and gyro heading was being set to the correct alliance’s pose and gyro heading. But when the robot was power cycled, our robot would always set the odometry pose and gyro heading to the blue side, and the path would veer towards the red side in a straight line to get to what the robot presumed to be the correct position.

We think that there is an issue with our logic for choosing the red or blue alliance to set the robot position and heading on the first path of our autos, but it’s just strange how the code works differently just after a power cycle.

I will point out that we are not using the AutoBuilder to reset our robot pose at the start of auto, and we are just using the libraries for following a singular path, setting the pose and heading right before the first follow path command of our auto is run. If AutoBuilder will fix this issue, we are willing to pivot to using it, but I would like to understand why resetting robot pose and heading manually is not working after the power cycle.

Here is our code for following PathPlanner paths, implemented into our Drivetrain subsystem class:

When we start autos, we call getPathCommand() with the DISCARDHEADING InitialPathState value, so that it sets the robot pose and heading based off of the pose and heading of the initial path’s start position.

Here is the method for determining whether the path should be inverted or not:

I’m at a loss right now trying to figure out this problem before our competition this weekend, so any help and suggestions would be greatly appreciated!

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
Shubbii:

We think that there is an issue with our logic for choosing the red or blue alliance to set the robot position and heading on the first path of our autos, but it’s just strange how the code works differently just after a power cycle.

The problem is that you’re calling getPathInvert() too early, before the alliance value is valid.  You don’t show the code, but I’m assuming you’re trying to do all of this (e.g. calling getPathCommand) from robotInit.  The alliance value is not guaranteed to be valid during robotInit, as the DS may not yet have connected.

EDIT: Checking in disabled won’t work, see replies.

A relatively easy workaround is to wait to set up the path until disabled, using code like the below to do a one-shot setup after getAlliance is valid:

Thank you for responding. I think I understand what you said because whenever the robot initializes after power cycling, it isn’t connected to the Driver station and would cause it to not have a value for the alliance color.

The thing that confuses me is that we aren’t calling getPathCommand in the robotInit() method, we are calling it in a command, which is used in our autonomous routines:

This Command is called in our auto routines. The only thing I think may be a problem is that we are adding all of the auto Commands to a SendableChooser class during robotInit(), which is used to choose our autos through ShuffleBoard:

We create an instance of RobotContainer in autonomousInit(), and call configureAutonomousRoutines() in the RobotContainer constructor.

Do you think it would help if we configured the SendableChooser after the Driver station Alliance is present?

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Peter_Johnson:

wait to set up the path until disabled

We see another post on CD that says Alliance isn’t guaranteed until autoInit() and that is our experience, too.

That’s why the PP example has a supplier to get the Alliance at “runtime”.

Use of the Optional for Alliance appears to be a Red Herring. We have seen at the start of a match setup the Alliance being null , then the wrong value, then null or the right value. Optional isn’t going to save you from using the wrong value.
I was wondering why the actual trajectory was able to flip when the command ran, but not our pose reset, and the double supplier explanation makes a lot of sense. Thank you!

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

We see another post on CD that says Alliance isn’t guaranteed until autoInit() and that is our experience, too.

That’s why the PP example has a supplier to get the Alliance at “runtime”.

Use of the Optional for Alliance appears to be a Red Herring. We have seen at the start of a match setup the Alliance being null , then the wrong value, then null or the right value.

Thinking about it, that makes sense.  When you plug your computer into the field, the DS can start communicating with the robot (thereby giving the wrong value) prior to the FMS connecting to the DS (giving the right value).  The robot code has no way of knowing whether it’s on the field or not.  Seems like some docs updates are in order.

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
What do you mean the optional returns null?  Do you mean it has an empty value? They’re very different. The optional itself for alliance is never null (or at least shouldn’t be).

As for the alliance on the field, there is a trick used by the ds where it should be impossible for the ds to connect without being fms connected. It should be impossible for a non fms connected packet to get through on the field. It’s possible there is a race condition on alliance setting however in the DS itself.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
I didn’t mean the Optional wasn’t working as Optional is intended. Sometimes the Alliance isn’t present (null) and that is correctly reported with Optional (but that isn’t helpful). Sometimes the Alliance is wrong (and that is painful) and Optional cannot help with that case.

I cannot diagnose a race condition but do understand from our WPIlogs the apparent order of initially no alliance, then the alliance from the driver station (wrong half the time), then the alliance from the FMS . The amount of time spent in each of these states does vary.

It all works out by the time autoInit() starts.

We had considered setting the match Alliance in our DS before connecting but that just adds to the administrative nightmare of the drive team following a pre-match checklist.

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked: One thing to double check, are you tethering to your robot before the match, and not fully rebooting the roboRIO before hooking to the field? A robot code reboot won’t reset the latched alliance station value, it has to be a full roboRIO reboot.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

I cannot diagnose a race condition but do understand from our WPIlogs the apparent order of initially no alliance, then the alliance from the driver station (wrong half the time), then the alliance from the FMS . The amount of time spent in each of these states does vary.

Can you share the relevant data logs?  Just post to Google Drive and PM a link works.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
I will share logs if they haven’t been cleaned out (we have to keep them on the roboRIO drive because the flash drive method doesn’t work often - another mystery).

I will not be able to relate the sequence of actions that @Thad_House was wondering about. It varies and the students wouldn’t be able to tell you accurately what they did a minute later. If there is a published sequence of match startup actions that are required to assure success, I haven’t seen it. IMG_2024-03-28_11-54-38 1200×1600 505 KB

IMG_2024-03-28_11-54-38 1200×1600 505 KB

IMG_2024-03-28_11-54-38 1200×1600 505 KB

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
We should definitely document the behavior here. The robot will latch alliance values (and other DS values), and the only way to clear them out is a full roborio reboot, not just a code reboot. So if you ever tether to the robot, and then go to the field without rebooting the roboRIO, you’ll get bad alliance values.

As for the log values, make sure you are looking at the FMSControlData key. The IsRedAlliance key will not properly show invalid state.

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
For 2024 and beyond, the best place to generate paths is the driverStationConnected() method you can overload on your robot class. That method is called at the beginning of the robot loop, the first time a DS connected.

Also, I wouldn’t call DriverStation.refreshData() manually. Doing so can cause missynchronized data packets and other weird issues.

link_counts.title: Accessing FMS Data for PathPlanner @ Beginning of Match

posts.cooked: Thank you for the help! We are re-configuring autos in both the driverStationConnected() method and in disabledPeriodic(), whenever the Alliance color in a previous robot loop does not match the current Alliance color. I tested this fix in Simulation, and it seems to work, but I will reply to this thread later to give final updates once I test on the actual robot.

We tested the robot today, and I think we made some pretty interesting discoveries and also managed to fix the pose reset at the start of autos!

Here’s what we changed:

In Robot.java, we now configure autonomous routines upon driverstation connection as opposed to simply configuring upon robot initialization.

We also now reconfigure our autos every time we change our driverstation alliance, so the autos will update accordingly.

Thank you for your support!

posts.name: fovea1959
posts.cooked:
Thad_House:

As for the log values, make sure you are looking at the FMSControlData key. The IsRedAlliance key will not properly show invalid state.

Would it be a good idea when getting wpilib ready for 2025 to deprecate the isRedAlliance() and encourage teams to use getAlliance()?

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked: IsRedAlliance is specifically a log key. There is no IsRedAlliance function in code. All that exists to user code is getAlliance().

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
We made getAlliance() return an optional this year to make it clearer that it can be invalid, but it seems like a lot of libraries or examples teams are using just ignore this fact and assume it’s a “default” color when it’s not yet set.  There’s not a lot we can do about this…

Making the driverStationAttached() TimedRobot function more visible next year may help somewhat to encourage teams to find out why that’s a different thing than robotInit, and maybe encourage libraries and examples to hook up there.
